blocks.text: Evidently the electric ray is constant in length and equal to a, the radius of the circle, and the limits to 0 and 2π, if the full area is required; hence.

blocks.latex: \int_{0}^{2\pi} \int_{0}^{a} r \, dr \, d\theta = \int_{0}^{2\pi} \left( \frac{r^{2}}{2} \right) \Bigg|_{0}^{a} d\theta = \int_{0}^{2\pi} \frac{a^{2}}{2} d\theta = \frac{a^{2}}{2} (2\pi) = \pi a^{2}.
blocks.description: This equation calculates the area of a circle using polar coordinates.

blocks.text: Example 4. Find the area of the solid angle given by the equation v = (1 + cos θ), ranging from 0 to π.
In this case $r$ is of variable length, but there is a definite connection between these variables, so we have to express the area in terms of $\theta$ and $r$. Hence.

blocks.latex: area = \int_{0}^{\pi} \int_{0}^{1 + cos \theta} r \, dr \, d\theta = \int_{0}^{\pi} \left( \frac{r^{2}}{2} \right) \Bigg|_{0}^{1 + cos \theta} d\theta = \int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{(1 + cos \theta)^{2}}{2} d\theta.
blocks.description: This equation calculates the area of the solid angle based on the variable length.

blocks.text: area = \int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1 + 2 cos \theta + cos^{2} \theta}{2} d\theta = \frac{1}{2} (\theta + sin \theta cos \theta) \Bigg|_{0}^{\pi} = \frac{1}{2} (\pi + 0 - 0) = \frac{\pi}{2}.
